hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Bakr ibn Abi Shaibah: Zaid ibn al-Hubab narrated to us from Ibn Lahiah who narrated to us from Yazid ibn Amr al-Ma'afiri, who said: I heard Abu Thaur saying that Abd al-Rahman ibn Udais al-Balawi came to us (and he was one of those who gave the oath of allegiance under the tree), and he praised Allah and spoke well of Him, then he mentioned Uthman. Abu Thaur said: I entered and he mentioned from Uthman may Allah be pleased with him the hadith.

potential_issues.impact: Ibn Lahiah is known for weak transmission, especially from non-Egyptian sources. His presence in the chain significantly weakens the hadith's authenticity.

potential_issues.issue: Chain is mawquf (stopped at Tabi'i level)

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abd al-Wahhab ibn Najdah al-Hawti: Ismail ibn Ayyash narrated to us from Bahir ibn Sa'd, from Khalid ibn Ma'dan, from Kathir ibn Murrah, from Numayy ibn Hammar may Allah be pleased with him, that a man came to the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ and asked: Which of the martyrs are the best? He ﷺ said: Those who meet the people in battle in a line and do not turn their faces until they are killed. Those are those who recline in the highest rooms of Paradise. Your Lord smiles at them, and when your Lord smiles at a slave in a place, there is no reckoning upon him.

potential_issues.issue: Ismail ibn Ayyash is a mudallis (subtle omitter in transmission chains)

He uses 'نا' (direct narration) here, but given his mudallis status, some scholars would require more explicit terms like 'سمعت'. However, since the subsequent narrators are Syrian and his transmission from them is generally accepted, this is mitigated. Nevertheless, it remains a potential issue.

potential_issues.issue: Multiple عَنْ terms indicating possible indirect transmission

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Muhammad ibn Musaffa: Abu al-Mughirah Abd al-Qudduds narrated to us from al-Walid ibn Sulaiman ibn Abi al-Sa'ib, he informed me Bushr ibn Ubayd Allah, from Abu Idris al-Khaulani, from Numayy ibn Hammar may Allah be pleased with him, that he heard the Messenger of Allah ﷺ saying: There is not any person except that his heart is between two fingers of the Merciful. If He wishes to cause it to go astray, He causes it to go astray, and if He wishes to set it straight, He sets it straight.
